text: How can childhood pneumonia affect the subsequent health of a person?	labels: Early life pneumonia can impair longterm lung health by decreasing lung function [6] . text: What is the increase in the risk of respiratory disease after having childhood pneumonia.	labels: The risk of developing at least one of the major sequelae was estimated as 6% after an ambulatory pneumonia event and 14% after an episode of hospitalized pneumonia.	episode_done:True

text: What is responsible for the reduction of radiologic pneumonia?	labels: Widespread use of pneumococcal conjugate vaccination and Haemophilus influenzae type B conjugate vaccination has decreased the incidence of radiologic pneumonia.	episode_done:True
text: What is the percentage reduction in pneumonia cases due to  vaccination?	labels: Haemophilus influenzae type B conjugate vaccination in high-burden communities, the vaccination was associated with an 18% decrease in radiologic pneumonia [13] . Introduction of pneumococcal conjugate vaccination was associated with a 26% decrease in radiologic pneumonia in California between 1995 and 1998 [14] . In vaccine efficacy trials in low-and middle-income countries, pneumococcal conjugate vaccination reduced radiologic pneumonia by 37% in the Gambia [15] , 25% in South Africa [16] and 26% in the Philippines 	episode_done:True

text: What is the effect of childhood tuberculosis in childhood pneumonia?	labels: A recent systematic review of tuberculosis as a comorbidity of childhood pneumonia reported culture-confirmed disease in about 8% of cases [50] . text: What are the risk factors in childhood pneumonia?	labels:  incomplete or inadequate vaccination must be considered as a major preventable risk factor for childhood pneumonia. Other risk factors include low birth weight, which is associated with 3.2 times increased odds of severe pneumonia in low-and middle-income countries, and 1.8 times increased odds in high-income countries [51] . Similarly, lack of exclusive breastfeeding for the first 4 months of life increases odds of severe pneumonia by 2.7 times in low-and middle-income countries and 1.3 times in highincome countries. 	episode_done:True

text: What is the strongest risk factor for childhood pneumonia?	labels: The single strongest risk factor for pneumonia is HIV infection, which is especially prevalent in children in sub-Saharan Africa. text: What is the global coverage of influenza and pneumonia vaccines?	labels:  By the end of 2015, Haemophilus influenzae type B conjugate vaccination had been introduced in 73 countries, with global coverage estimated at 68%. text: Is influenza vaccination during pregnancy safe? text: What is discussed in this publication?	labels: the potential anti-virus activity of inositol-requiring enzyme 1 (IRE1), a well characterized effector of the cellular homeostatic response to an overloading of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) protein-folding capacity. IRE1, an ER-membrane-resident ribonuclease (RNase), upon activation catalyses regulated cleavage of select protein-coding and non-coding host RNAs, using an RNase domain which is homologous to that of the known anti-viral effector RNaseL. 	episode_done:True
text: What is discussed in this publication?	labels: The review first discusses the anti-viral mechanism of the OAS/RNaseL system and evasion tactics employed by different viruses. text: What is reported in this publication?	labels: comparison of the enzymatic activity of the two RNases followed by deliberations on the physiological consequences of their activation.	episode_done:True
text: What is the conclusion regarding IRE1 and RNaseL proteins?	labels: In the context of a virus infection, the pathway leading from both these proteins have the potential to lead to cell death. Notwithstanding the fact that this might be an efficient way of virus clearance, it also portends pathological outcomes for the infected organism. Future research would probably lead to design of drugs targeting these proteins based on the structural homology of their effector domains, regulating the pathological denouement of their activation without compromising their anti-viral or potential anti-viral functions.	episode_done:True

text: What was done to test if  an intermediate host may not be necessary and that some bat SL-CoVs may be able to directly infect human hosts. T	labels:  the exact S gene from bat coronavirus SL-SHC014 was synthesized and used to generate a chimeric virus in the mouse adapted MA15 SARS-CoV backbone. 	episode_done:True
text: What were the results of this test?	labels: The resultant SL-SHC014-MA15 virus could indeed efficiently use human ACE2 and replicate in primary human airway cells to similar titres as epidemic strains of SARS-CoV. text: Why is there  no credible evidence to support the claim that the SARS-CoV-2 is derived from the chimeric SL-SHC014-MA15 virus?	labels: upon careful phylogenetic analyses by multiple international groups [5, 14] , the SARS-CoV-2 is undoubtedly distinct from SL-SHC014-MA15, with >6,000 nucleotide differences across the whole genome.	episode_done:True

text: What happened to the report with initial claims?	labels:  Because of the many concerns raised by the international community, the authors who made the initial claim have already withdrawn this report.	episode_done:True
text: What is the difference between evolution and synthetic constructs?	labels: Evolution is stepwise and accrues mutations gradually over time, whereas synthetic constructs would typically use a known backbone and introduce logical or targeted changes instead of the randomly occurring mutations that are present in naturally isolated viruses such as bat CoV RaTG13.	episode_done:True
text: What is the conclusion of this report?	labels:  there is currently no credible evidence to support the claim that SARS-CoV-2 originated from a laboratory-engineered CoV. It is more likely that SARS-CoV-2 is a recombinant CoV generated in nature between a bat CoV and another coronavirus in an intermediate animal host. 	episode_done:True
text: What is the conclusion of this report?	labels: More studies are needed to explore this possibility and resolve the natural origin of SARS-CoV-2. We should emphasize that, although SARS-CoV-2 shows no evidence of laboratory origin, viruses with such great public health threats must be handled properly in the laboratory and also properly regulated by the scientific community and governments.	episode_done:True

text: What are examples of delivery vectors for commercial anti-Salmonella vaccines?	labels: Ty21a for typhoid fever in humans, several Salmonella serovars against salmonellosis in chickens and other animals	episode_done:True
text: What can be a factor in using common vectors for the delivery of vaccines?	labels: commonly employed vectors, for example Salmonella and adenovirus, often have pre-existing immune responses in the host and this has the potential to modify the subsequent immune response to a vectored antigen. 	episode_done:True
text: Is a pre-existing immune response to commonly used delivery vector an advantage or a disadvantage?	labels: for bacterial vectors there can in fact, in some cases, be an enhancement in immunogenicity, typically humoral, while for viral vectors pre-existing immunity is a hindrance for subsequent induction of cell-mediated responses.	episode_done:True
text: What bacterial delivery vectors have been tested in animal hosts?	labels:  attenuated bacteria, including Escherichia coli, Vibrio cholerae, lactic acid bacteria (LAB), specifically Lactococcus lactis, Mycobacterium, Listeria, Shigella and Salmonella, have been tested for the targeted delivery of heterologous antigens of bacterial, viral and parasitic origin into a variety of animal hosts	episode_done:True

text: Why are E Coli and lactic acid are safe choices as delivery vectors for vaccines?	labels: E. coli is a commensal and lactic acid bacteria are present in most fermented food items and are therefore naturally present in the host. text: What is Listeria?	labels:  Listeria species are Gram-positive intracellular food-borne pathogens	episode_done:True
text: What is the advantage of Listeria as a  delivery vector for vaccines?	labels: The advantages of Listeria are that it can invade a variety of cells, including antigen presenting cells (APCs). After invading the host cell, Listeria resides inside the phagosome; however, it can escape the phagosome with the help of listeriolysin O (LLO; Hly) and reside in the cytoplasm of the cells, thereby efficiently presenting antigen to both CD8 and CD4 T cells 	episode_done:True
text: What are examples of  viral vectors for delivering vaccines?	labels: recombinant vaccines are based on both DNA viruses (such as fowlpox virus-based vaccines which target avian influenza virus and fowlpox virus, or vaccinia virusbased vectors against the rabies virus in wildlife) and RNA viruses [such as Newcastle disease virus-based vaccines to be used in poultry or yellow fever virus (YFV)-based vaccines to be used in horses against West Nile virus] 	episode_done:True

text: What is the advantage of adenovirus as vaccine delivery vector?	labels: adenovirus (Ad) vector is another of the most widely evaluated vectors to date to express heterologous antigens, due to ease of production, safety profile, genetic stability, the ease of DNA genome manipulation, and the ability to stimulate both innate and adaptive immune responses and induce both T and B cell responses 	episode_done:True

text: What happens when a recipient of a vaccine has immune response to the delivery vector?	labels: considering a vector such as Salmonella, if a host has previously been infected there will exist robust B and T memory responses, and as such, when a vaccination is delivered, an anamnestic response to the Salmonella antigens will be induced (while the response to the vectored antigen will be a primary response)	episode_done:True
text: What is the effect of host immune response to the delivery vector on the efficacy of vaccination?	labels: for virally vectored antigens, the existence of pre-existing immunity to the vector (particularly neutralizing antibody) will restrict delivery of the virus into cells, thereby effectively reducing the dose of the vectored antigen. Again, this might be expected to result in a reduction in the antigenicity of the vectored antigen.	episode_done:True
text: What is the effect of host immune response to the delivery vector on the efficacy of vaccination?	labels: theoretically reduce the exposure of the heterologous antigen to the immune system, as the vector is rapidly cleared.	episode_done:True
text: What is an example  of the effect of immunity to the  delivery vector on the efficacy of vaccination?	labels: mice that had been primed with Salmonella alone, and then boosted with Salmonella expressing tetC, induced much lower anti-tetC responses than mice that had not been primed. This argues strongly that prior immunological immunity to the vector can seriously dampen subsequent antigen-specific humoral responses.	episode_done:True
text: What is the effect of host immune response to viral delivery vectors in the efficacy of vaccination?	labels: pre-existing immunity is a major obstacle of many viralvectored vaccines, such as Ad serotype 5 or herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1), where the rate of seroprevalence to these viruses is very high [40-45 % and 70 % (or more) of the US population, respectively] 	episode_done:True
text: What is the effect of host immune response to  the viral delivery vector on the efficacy of vaccination?	labels: Vector-specific antibodies may impede the induction of immune responses to the vaccine-encoded antigens, as they may reduce the dose and time of exposure of the target cells to the vaccinated antigens	episode_done:True

text: What are methods to avoid the effect vector immunity on the efficacy of vaccination?	labels:  the use of vectors derived from nonhuman sources, using human viruses of rare serotypes (Kahl et al., 2010; Lasaro & Ertl, 2009) , heterologous prime-boost approaches (Liu et al., 2008) , homologous reimmunization (Steffensen et al., 2012) and removing key neutralizing epitopes on the surface of viral capsid proteins (Gabitzsch & Jones, 2011; Roberts et al., 2006) 	episode_done:True
text: What are methods to  avoid the effect of vector immune response on the efficacy of vaccination?	labels: The inhibitory effect of pre-existing immunity can also be avoided by masking the Ad vector inside dendritic cells (DCs) (Steffensen et al., 2012) . In addition, mucosal vaccination or administration of higher vaccine doses can overcome pre-existing immunity problems (Alexander et al., 2012; Belyakov et al., 1999; Priddy et al., 2008; Xiang et al., 2003) . 	episode_done:True
text: How does cell-mediated immunity to viral delivery vector, reduce the immune response to vaccine?	labels:  this is because viruses will induce neutralizing antibody on the first dose, and in subsequent doses this antibody will limit the number of transduced cells, therefore limiting the responses. This is particularly a problem with a common viral vector such as Ad, where a large proportion of the population will have immunological memory against common serotypes	episode_done:True
text: How can vectors for which host has immunity, be used differently to increase the efficacy of vaccination?	labels:  it will be possible to utilize such vectors only by developing vaccines from alternative serotypes. It may be that a vector such as Pre-existing immunity against vaccine vectors attenuated influenza virus, with the ability to easily develop reassortants, will be useful in this context.  In addition, immunological memory in the form of opsonizing antibody certainly plays an important role in the early uptake of Salmonella by macrophages and DC. This may be beneficial, as the live bacterial vector used for delivery purposes harbours mutations in genes encoding proteins responsible for their survival in the animal host. This not only encumbers their ability to cause disease, making them safe live vectors, but also limits the number of replications. The presence of opsonizing antibodies should mean a higher level of bacterial uptake, leading to higher presentation to the immune system and therefore a better immune response.	episode_done:True

text: What is Koch's first postulate?	labels: The microbe occurs in every case of the disease in question and under circumstances which can account for the pathological changes and clinical course of the disease	episode_done:True

text: What is the regularity of the virion major coat protein lattice useful for? 	labels:  enables a variety of bioconjugation and surface chemistry applications, particularly in nanomaterials	episode_done:True
text: Why is the phage ab excellent model system for directed protein evolution?	labels: the phageâs large population sizes and fast generation times	episode_done:True
text: What are filamentous bacteriophages genera Inovirua and Plectrovirus?	labels: non-enveloped, rod-shaped viruses of Escherichia coli whose long helical capsids encapsulate a single-stranded circular DNA genome.	episode_done:True
text: What invention has made bacteriophage useful for research?	labels: principle of modifying the filamentous phage genome to display polypeptides as fusions to coat proteins on the virion surface 	episode_done:True
text: What has the bacteriphage technology and the library of folded protein variants enabled?	labels: the ability to seamlessly connect genetic information with protein function for a large number of protein variants simultaneously, and has been widely and productively exploited in studies of proteinprotein interactions	episode_done:True
text: What are the potential novel applications of the filamentous phage?	labels: (i) filamentous phage as a vaccine carrier; (ii) engineered filamentous phage as a therapeutic biologic agent in infectious and chronic diseases; (iii) filamentous phage as a scaffold for bioconjugation and surface chemistry; and (iv) filamentous phage as an engine for evolving variants of displayed proteins with novel functions. 	episode_done:True
text: What themes are common in  the applications of filamentous phage?	labels:  unique biological, immunological, and physicochemical properties of the phage, its ability to display a variety of biomolecules in modular fashion, and its relative simplicity and ease of manipulation	episode_done:True
text: What do applications of filamentous phage depend on?	labels: its ability to display polypeptides on the virion's surface as fusions to phage coat proteins 	episode_done:True
text: What characteristics are determined by the display  mode?	labels:  maximum tolerated size of the fused polypeptide, its copy number on the phage, and potentially, the structure of the displayed polypeptide	episode_done:True
text: How may the display be achieved?	labels:  by fusing DNA encoding a polypeptide of interest directly to the gene encoding a coat protein within the phage genome (type 8 display on pVIII, type 3 display on pIII, etc.)	episode_done:True
text: What does  the term "phage display" refer to?	labels:  a recombinant filamentous phage displaying a single polypeptide sequence on its surface (or more rarely, bispecific display achieved via fusion of polypeptides to two different capsid proteins)	episode_done:True
text: What does the term "phage displayed library" refer to?	labels: a diverse pool of recombinant filamentous phage displaying an array of polypeptide variants (e.g., antibody fragments; peptides)	episode_done:True
text: What characteristic of filamentous phage has been demonstrated?	labels: is highly immunogenic in the absence of adjuvants (Meynell and Lawn, 1968 ) and that only the major coat protein, pVIII, and the minor coat protein, pIII, are targeted by antibodies	episode_done:True
text: What application is a natural extension of the  ability to display recombinant exogenous sequences on its surface?	labels: as carrier to elicit antibodies against poorly immunogenic haptens or polypeptide	episode_done:True
text: What makes it an attractive vaccine carrier?	labels: The phage particle's low cost of production, high stability and potential for high valency display of foreign antigen	episode_done:True
text: What does the display mode determine?	labels:  the maximum tolerated size of the fused polypeptide, its copy number on the phage, and potentially, the structure of the displayed polypeptide. 	episode_done:True
text: Why are antibody epitope based peptide vaccines are no longer an active research area?	labels: (i) in many cases, peptides incompletely or inadequately mimic epitopes on folded proteins (Irving et al., 2010 ; see below); (ii) antibodies against a single epitope may be of limited utility, especially for highly variable pathogens (Van Regenmortel, 2012); and (iii) for pathogens for which protective immune responses are generated efficiently during natural infection, peptide vaccines offer few advantages over recombinant subunit and live vector vaccines, which have become easier to produce over time.	episode_done:True
text: What phage may be useful in allergy immunotherapy?	labels: Phage displaying peptide ligands of an anti-IgE antibody elicited antibodies that bound purified IgE molecules	episode_done:True
text: Which are some phage based contraceptive vaccines for animals?	labels:  immunization with phage displaying follicle-stimulating hormone peptides on pVIII elicited antibodies that impaired the fertility of mice and ewes 	episode_done:True
text: Which are some phage based contraceptive vaccines for animals?	labels: Phage displaying or chemically Rubinchik and Chow (2000) conjugated to sperm antigen peptides or peptide mimics (Samoylova et al., 2012a,b) and gonadotropin-releasing hormone (Samoylov et al., 2012) are also in development.	episode_done:True
text: What is one reason for the lack of success of immunization phage displayed peptides with native protein?	labels:  it seems that peptide antigens elicit a set of topologically restricted antibodies that are largely unable to recognize discontinuous or complex epitopes on larger biomolecules. While the peptide may mimic the chemistry of a given epitope on a folded protein (allowing it to crossreact with a targeted antibody), being a smaller molecule, it cannot mimic the topology of that antibody's full epitope.	episode_done:True
text: Despite shortcomings, what has the filamentous phage has been useful for?	labels: as a carrier for peptides with relatively simple secondary structures, which may be stablilized via anchoring to the coat proteins (Henry et al., 2011) . This may be especially true of peptides with poor inherent immunogenicity, which may be increased by high-valency display and phage-associated adjuvanticity	episode_done:True
text: What is the result of all species tests of phage particles?	labels:  is immunogenic without adjuvant in all species tested to date, including mice (Willis et al., 1993) , rats (Dente et al., 1994) , rabbits (de la Cruz et al., 1988) , guinea pigs (Frenkel et al., 2000; Kim et al., 2004) , fish (Coull et al., 1996; Xia et al., 2005) , non-human primates (Chen et al., 2001) , and humans (Roehnisch et al., 2014) 	episode_done:True
text: What are the results of filamentous phage immunizations in mice?	labels: serum antibody titers against the phage typically reach 1:10 5 -1:10 6 after 2-3 immunizations, and are maintained for at least 1 year postimmunization (Frenkel et al., 2000) . 	episode_done:True
text: What is the primary antibody response against the phage?	labels: composed of a mixture of IgM and IgG2b isotypes in C57BL/6 mice, while secondary antibody responses are composed primarily of IgG1 and IgG2b isotypes, with a lesser contribution of IgG2c and IgG3 isotypes (Hashiguchi et al., 2010) .	episode_done:True
text: Why is phage self-adjuvanting?	labels: Host cell wall-derived LPS enhances the virion's immunogenicity, and its removal by polymyxin B chromatography reduces antibody titers against phage coat proteins (Grabowska et al., 2000) . The phage's singlestranded DNA genome contains CpG motifs and may also have an adjuvant effect. 	episode_done:True
text: On what does the antibody  response to phage depend on?	labels: MyD88 signaling and is modulated by stimulation of several Toll-like receptors (Hashiguchi et al., 2010) , indicating that innate immunity plays an important 	episode_done:True
text: What do biodistribution studies of the phage after intravenous injection show?	labels:  it is cleared from the blood within hours through the reticuloendothelial system (Molenaar et al., 2002) , particularly of the liver and spleen, where it is retained for days (Zou et al., 2004) , potentially activating marginal-zone B-cell responses. 	episode_done:True
text: What are the merits of the filamentous phage carriers?	labels:  the filamentous phage is not only a highly immunogenic carrier, but by virtue of activating a range of innate and adaptive immune responses, serves as an excellent model virus-like particle antigen.	episode_done:True
text: What is a future potential of filamentous phage?	labels:  as elements of combination therapeutics against certain drug-resistant infections.	episode_done:True
text: What were more potent inhibitors of Staphylococcus aureus growth than high-concentration free chloramphenicol?	labels: M13 or fd phage displaying either a targeting peptide or antibody fragment and tethered to chloramphenicol by a labile crosslinker 	episode_done:True
text: What killed prostate cancer cells in vitro?	labels: M13 phage loaded with doxorubicin and displaying a targeting peptide on pIII	episode_done:True

(2007) showed that phage displaying peptides and/or Fabs specific for tumor antigens delayed tumor growth and improved survival, owing in large part to activation of tumor-associated macrophages and recruitment of neutrophils to the tumor site (Eriksson et al., 2009) 	episode_done:True

text: What is the structure of a filamentous phage particle?	labels: is enclosed by a rod-like protein capsid, â¼1000 nm long and 5 nm wide, made up almost entirely of overlapping pVIII monomers, each of which lies â¼27 angstroms from its nearest neighbor and exposes two amine groups as well as at least three carboxyl groups (Henry et al., 2011)	episode_done:True
text: What makes filamentous phage ideal scaffold for bioconjugation?	labels: The regularity of the phage pVIII lattice and its diversity of chemically addressable groups	episode_done:True
text: What trials have been done to demonstrate the potential of phage in applications for nanomaterials?	labels: Lee et al. (2002) engineered M13 phage to display a ZnS-binding peptide on pIII and showed that, in the presence of ZnS nanoparticles, they selfassemble into highly ordered film biomaterials that can be aligned using magnetic fields.	episode_done:True
text: What trials have been done to demonstrate the potential of phage in applications for nanomaterials?	labels: Taking advantage of the ability to display substrate-specific peptides at known locations on the phage filament Hess et al., 2012) , this pioneering FIGURE 3 | Chemically addressable groups of the filamentous bacteriophage major coat protein lattice. 	episode_done:True
text: What is the filamentous phage varion is made of?	labels: made up of â¼2,500-4,000 overlapping copies of the 50-residue major coat protein, pVIII, arranged in a shingle-type lattice. Each monomer has an array of chemically addressable groups available for bioorthogonal conjugation, including two primary amine groups (shown in red), three carboxyl groups (show in blue) and two hydroxyl groups (show in green). The 12 N-terminal residues generally exposed to the immune system for antibody binding 	episode_done:True

text: What was the purpose of the search?	labels:  to identify published studies examining the diagnosis, therapeutic drugs and vaccines for Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS), Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) and the 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV), in accordance with the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines.	episode_done:True
text: What topics were searched for?	labels: randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and validation trials (for diagnostics test) published in English, that measured (a) the sensitivity and/or specificity of a rapid diagnostic test or a point-of-care testing kit, (b) the impact of drug therapy or (c) vaccine efficacy against either of these diseases with no date restriction applied. For the 2019-nCoV, we searched for all in vitro, animal, or human studies published in English between 1 December 2019 and 6 February 2020, on the same outcomes of interest. 	episode_done:True
text: What studies  were excluded?	labels:  Studies that examined the mechanisms of diagnostic tests, drug therapy or vaccine efficacy against SARS, MERS and 2019-nCoV	episode_done:True
text: What did the searches yield?	labels: A Google search for 2019-nCoV diagnostics (as of 6 February 2020; Table S2 ) yielded five webpage links from government and international bodies with official information and guidelines (WHO, Europe CDC, US CDC, US FDA), three webpage links on diagnostic protocols and scientific commentaries, and five webpage links on market news and press releases. Six protocols for diagnostics using reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) from six countries were published on WHO's website [9] . Google search for 2019-nCoV vaccines yielded 19 relevant articles.	episode_done:True

text: What role rapid diagnostics plays?	labels: enables prompt and accurate public health surveillance, prevention and control measures. Local transmission and clusters can be prevented or delayed by isolation of laboratory-confirmed cases and their close contacts quarantined and monitored at home	episode_done:True
text: What other measures rapid diagnostics facilitates?	labels: specific public health interventions such as closure of high-risk facilities and areas associated with the confirmed cases for prompt infection control and environmental decontamination 	episode_done:True
text: What  are ways to perform laboratory diagnostics?	labels:  (a) detecting the genetic material of the virus, (b) detecting the antibodies that neutralize the viral particles of interest, (c) detecting the viral epitopes of interest with antibodies (serological testing), or (d) culture and isolation of viable virus particles.	episode_done:True
text: What are key limtations of genetic detection?	labels: lack of knowledge of the presence of viable virus, the potential cross-reactivity with non-specific genetic regions and the short timeframe for accurate detection during the acute infection phase.	episode_done:True
text: What is a key limitation of serological  testing?	labels: the need to collect paired serum samples (in the acute and convalescent phases) from cases under investigation for confirmation to eliminate potential cross-reactivity from non-specific antibodies from past exposure and/or infection by other coronaviruses.	episode_done:True
text: What is the limitation in virus testing?	labels:  the long duration and the highly specialized skills required of the technicians to process the samples. 	episode_done:True

text: What is the Newcastle disease virus?	labels: a single-stranded, negative-sense RNA virus that causes disease in poultry. 	episode_done:True
text: What are the appealing qualities of the NDV vector?	labels: As an avian virus, there is little or no preexisting immunity to NDV in humans and NDV propagates to high titers in both chicken eggs and cell culture. 	episode_done:True
text: What is the appealing quality of the NDV vector?	labels: As a paramyxovirus, there is no DNA phase in the virus lifecycle reducing concerns of integration events, and the levels of gene expression are driven by the proximity to the leader sequence at the 3' end of the viral genome. This gradient of gene expression enables attenuation through rearrangement of the genome, or by insertion of transgenes within the genome.	episode_done:True
text: What is the appealing quality of the NDV vector?	labels: pathogenicity of NDV is largely determined by features of the fusion protein enabling ready attenuation of the vaccine vector	episode_done:True
text: What did the first report on the NDV vector test conclude?	labels: it induced a robust serum antibody response and protected against homologous influenza virus challenge in a murine model of infection 	episode_done:True
text: What is the added protection of NDV vector?	labels: providing protection against both the influenza virus and NDV infection.	episode_done:True
text: What have the limited NDV human trails shown?	labels: the NDV vector is well-tolerated, even at high doses delivered intravenously 	episode_done:True
text: What  are the attractive features of the PIV5 vector?	labels:  PIV5 has a stable RNA genome and no DNA phase in virus replication cycle reducing concerns of host genome integration or modification. PIV5 can be grown to very high titers in mammalian vaccine cell culture substrates and is not cytopathic allowing for extended culture and harvest of vaccine virus [98, 99] . Like NDV, PIV5 has a 3'-to 5' gradient of gene expression and insertion of transgenes at different locations in the genome can variably attenuate the virus and alter transgene expression [100] . PIV5 has broad tropism, infecting many cell types, tissues, and species without causing clinical disease, although PIV5 has been associated with -kennel coughâ in dogs	episode_done:True
text: What  was the result of the test of efficacy of PIV5 in murine challenge?	labels: Mice intranasally vaccinated with a single dose of PIV5-H5 vaccine had robust serum and mucosal antibody responses, and were protected from lethal challenge. text: How are the ribozymes able to replicate, join and create peptide bonds?	labels:  They can polymerize progeny chemically, allow for mutations to occur and can evolve. One molecule serves as catalyst, the other one as substrate. Replication of ribozymes was demonstrated in the test tube (Lincoln and Joyce, 2009) . Ribozymes can form peptide bonds between amino acids (Zhang and Cech, 1997) . Thus, small peptides were available by ribozyme activity. 	episode_done:True
text: Does RNA replication need polymerase enzymes?	labels: Replication of RNA molecules can be performed chemically from RNA without polymerase enzymes.	episode_done:True
text: How can DNA arise chemically from RNA?	labels: deoxyribozymes can form from ribonucleotides (Wilson and Szostak, 1999) . Thus, DNA can arise from RNA chemically, without the key protein enzyme, the reverse transcriptase.	episode_done:True

text: What do ribozymes lack?	labels: the genetic triplet code and do not encode proteins	episode_done:True
text: What do ribozymes exhibit?	labels: structural information by hairpin-loops that form hydrogen bonds between incomplete double strands, and loops free to interact with other molecules.	episode_done:True

text: What is the conclusion of  this report?	labels:  heightened immune responses limit pathogen-induced cellular morbidity, which can facilitate the establishment of rapidly-propagating persistent infections within-host. text: Why  have bats received attention in recent years?	labels: for their role as reservoir hosts for emerging viral zoonoses, including rabies and related lyssaviruses, Hendra and Nipah henipaviruses, Ebola and Marburg filoviruses, and SARS coronavirus 	episode_done:True
text: What difference bats demonstrate compared to most non-Chiropteran mammals?	labels: no obvious disease symptoms upon infection with pathogens that are highly virulent in non-volant mammals (Schountz et al., 2017) but may, instead, support viruses as longterm persistent infections, rather than transient, immunizing pathologies	episode_done:True
text: What suite of species-specific mechanisms do bats have to limit viral load?	labels: host receptor sequence incompatibilities for some bat-virus combinations (Ng et al., 2015; Takadate et al., 2020) and constitutive expression of the antiviral cytokine	episode_done:True
text: How are mammalian cells typically rendered antiviral?	labels:  the presence of viral RNA or DNA in the cytoplasm of mammalian cells will induce secretion of type I interferon proteins (IFN-a and IFN-b), which promote expression and translation of interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) in neighboring cells 	episode_done:True
text: In non-flying mammals, what what would be elicited by IFN expression upon viral infection?	labels: widespread inflammation and concomitant immunopathology upon viral infection	episode_done:True
text: What do the bats do instead?	labels: bats support unique adaptations to combat inflammation	episode_done:True
text: Why may the bats have this unique adaptation?	labels: to mitigate metabolic damage induced during flight	episode_done:True
text: Why  was the field of virus dynamics developed?	labels: to describe the mechanistic underpinnings of long-term patterns of steady-state viral load exhibited by patients in chronic phase infections with HIV, who appeared to produce and clear virus at equivalent rates 	episode_done:True
text: How are bats connected to fatal viral diseases?	labels: bats are natural reservoirs for viruses that have some of the highest fatality rates of any viruses that people acquire from wild animals -including rabies, Ebola and the SARS coronavirus.	episode_done:True
text: What is  an example of anti-viral defense in bats?	labels: some bats have an antiviral immune response called the interferon pathway perpetually switched on	episode_done:True
text: What would be caused by  this hyper-vigilance in most other mammals?	labels:  harmful inflammation	episode_done:True
text: How are bats different?	labels: Bats, however, have adapted anti-inflammatory traits that protect them from such harm, include the loss of certain genes that normally promote inflammation.	episode_done:True
text: What bat species cells were compared?	labels: -the black flying fox -in which the interferon pathway is always on, and another -the Egyptian fruit bat -in which this pathway is only activated during an infection.	episode_done:True
text: What was the conclusion of the study ?	labels:  In both bat species, the strongest antiviral responses were countered by the virus spreading more quickly from cell to cell. This suggests that bat immune defenses may drive the evolution of faster transmitting viruses, and while bats are well protected from the harmful effects of their own prolific viruses, other creatures like humans are not.	episode_done:True
text: What would be the benefit of learning more about bat's defenses and how they  drive virus evolution?	labels: help scientists develop better ways to predict, prevent or limit the spread of viruses from bats to humans. 	episode_done:True
text: Which cells are IFN-defective and therefore limited in  antiviral capacity?	labels: demonstrate idiosyncratic induced interferon responses upon viral challenge	episode_done:True
text: What cells demonstrate idiosyncratic interferon response?	labels: RoNi/7.1 (Rousettus aegyptiacus) cells	episode_done:True
text: Which cells express constitutive IFN-a?	labels: PaKiT01 (Pteropus alecto) cell	episode_done:True
text: How were  the spread of GFP-expressing virus-infected cells across tissue monolayers tracked via inverted fluorescence microscopy?	labels: Because plaque assays restrict viral transmission neighbor-to-neighbor in two-dimensional cellular space 	episode_done:True
text: How were  the spread of GFP-expressing virus-infected cells tracked?	labels:  For each infection trial, we monitored and re-imaged plates for up to 200 hr of observations or until total monolayer destruction, processed resulting images, and generated a time series of the proportion of infectious-cell occupied plate space across the duration of each trial (see Materials and methods). We used generalized additive models to infer the time course of all cell culture replicates and construct the multi-trial dataset to which we eventually fit our mechanistic transmission model for each cell line-virus-specific combinatio	episode_done:True
text: How was the modeling carried out?	labels: an innovative combination of in vitro experimentation and within-host modeling to explore the impact of unique bat immunity on virus dynamics.	episode_done:True
text: What was the finding in this study?	labels: that bat cell lines demonstrated a signature of enhanced interferon-mediated immune response, of either constitutive or induced form, which allowed for establishment of rapid within-host, cell-to-cell virus transmission rates 	episode_done:True
text: What supports the results?	labels: by both data-independent bifurcation analysis of our mean field theoretical model, as well as fitting of this model to viral infection time series established in bat cell culture.	episode_done:True
text: What was additionally demonstrated?	labels: the antiviral state induced by the interferon pathway protects live cells from mortality in tissue culture, resulting in in vitro epidemics of extended duration that enhance the probability of establishing a long-term persistent infection.	episode_done:True
text: What do  the studies suggest?	labels: that viruses evolved in bat reservoirs possessing enhanced IFN capabilities could achieve more rapid within-host transmission rates without causing pathology to their hosts. Such rapidly-reproducing viruses would likely generate extreme virulence upon spillover to hosts lacking similar immune capacities to bats.	episode_done:True
text: What was the methodology for this study?	labels: we first developed a novel, within-host, theoretical model elucidating the effects of unique bat immunity, then undertook bifurcation analysis of the model's equilibrium properties under immune absent, induced, and constitutive assumptions. We considered a cell line to be constitutively immune if possessing any number of antiviral cells at disease-free equilibrium but allowed the extent of constitutive immunity to vary across the parameter range for ", the constitutive rate of antiviral acquisition. 	episode_done:True
text: What was demonstrated in deriving the equation for R 0?	labels:  invasion threshold is elevated at high values of constitutive antiviral acquisition,	episode_done:True
text: What is a conclusion of the modeling?	labels: Constitutive immune processes can thus prohibit pathogen invasion, while induced responses, by definition, can only control infections post-hoc.	episode_done:True
text: What is a conclusion of the study?	labels: Regardless of mechanism (induced or constitutive), interferon-stimulated antiviral cells appear to play a key role in maintaining longer term or persistent infections by safeguarding susceptible cells from rapid infection and concomitant cell death. 	episode_done:True
text: What do  fits to rVSV-MARV infections on PaKiT01 cells suggest?	labels: that the constitutive IFN-a expression characteristic of P. alecto cells may represent more of a constitutive immune priming process than a perpetual, functional, antiviral defense.	episode_done:True
text: What do the findings indicate?	labels: enhanced IFN-mediated immune pathways in bat reservoirs may promote elevated within-host virus replication rates prior to cross-species emergence. 	episode_done:True
text: What is presented in this study?	labels: general methods to study cross-scale viral dynamics, which suggest that within-host persistence is supported by robust antiviral responses characteristic of bat immune processes. 	episode_done:True
text: What is a conclusion of  this study?	labels:  Viruses which evolve rapid replication rates under these robust antiviral defenses may pose the greatest hazard for cross-species pathogen emergence into spillover hosts with immune systems that differ from those unique to bats. 	episode_done:True

text: What is the reason to adopt low-dose CT?	labels:  low-dose chest CT has been widely used in the screening of early lung cancer. It is well known that many early lung cancers are ground-glass opacities (GGO), so we believe that low-dose screening is also applicable for COVID-19. In addition, considering the rapid development of COVID-19, many CT 14 examinations may be conducted in the same individual to monitor disease progress. Low-dose scanning can reduce the radiation damage to patients.	episode_done:True

text: What  could account for the high transmission rate of the 2019-nCOV virus?	labels: Intensive structural analysis of the S protein of 2019-nCoV with the SARS-Coronavirus suggested that several critical residues in the viral spike protein might confer favourable interaction with human ACE2 [7] . text: What have the authors reviewed?	labels: the prevalence of different respiratory viral infections in causing exacerbations in chronic airway inflammatory diseases.	episode_done:True

text: What is consolidated in this review?	labels: the understanding of viral induced exacerbation in chronic airway inflammatory diseases and indicates pathways that may be targeted for more effective management of chronic inflammatory diseases.	episode_done:True
text: What is this disease  characterized by ?	labels:  airway inflammation leading to complications such as coughing, wheezing and shortness of breath. 	episode_done:True
text: Where can this disease manifest?	labels:  in both the upper airway (such as chronic rhinosinusitis, CRS) and lower airway (such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, COPD)	episode_done:True
text: Why do treatment and management vary in efficacy?	labels: due to the complexity and heterogeneity of the disease.	episode_done:True
text: What complicates this  further?	labels: the effect of episodic exacerbations of the disease, defined as worsening of disease symptoms including wheeze, cough, breathlessness and chest tightness 	episode_done:True
text: What are such exacerbations due to?	labels: the effect of enhanced acute airway inflammation impacting upon and worsening the symptoms of the existing disease	episode_done:True
text: What do the acute exacerbations cause?	labels: morbidity and sometimes mortality in patients, as well as resulting in major economic burdens worldwide	episode_done:True
text: What are acute exacerbations  usually due to ?	labels: the presence of environmental factors such as allergens, pollutants, smoke, cold or dry air and pathogenic microbes in the airway	episode_done:True
text: What does the immune response elicited by these agents lead to?	labels:  infiltration of activated immune cells that further release inflammatory mediators that cause acute symptoms such as increased mucus production, cough, wheeze and shortness of breath. 	episode_done:True
text: Among these agents which is a major driver?	labels: viral infection is one of the major drivers of asthma exacerbations accounting for up to 80-90% and 45-80% of exacerbations in children and adults respectively	episode_done:True
text: What is the viral involvement in COPD exacerbation? 	labels: 30-80% of acute COPD exacerbations	episode_done:True
text: What is the reason for the involvement of respiratory viruses in exacerbation?	labels: their ease of transmission and infection	episode_done:True
text: What does the involvement of respiratory viruses contribute to?	labels:  important to identify the exact mechanisms underpinning viral exacerbations in susceptible subjects	episode_done:True
text: Why is it  important to identify the exact mechanisms underpinning viral exacerbations in susceptible subjects?	labels:  to properly manage exacerbations via supplementary treatments that may alleviate the exacerbation symptoms or prevent severe exacerbations.	episode_done:True
text: What is the lower airway the site of?	labels: dysregulated inflammation in most chronic airway inflammatory diseases	episode_done:True
text: Where is the the first point of contact with sources of exacerbation	labels: the upper airway	episode_done:True
text: What is the focus of this review?	labels:  recent findings of viral interaction with the upper airway.	episode_done:True
text: What is complied by the authors?	labels: how viral induced changes to the upper airway may contribute to chronic airway inflammatory disease exacerbations, to provide a unified elucidation of the potential exacerbation mechanisms initiated from predominantly upper airway infections.	episode_done:True
text: Before linking respiratory viruses, what was linked to acute exacerbations?	labels: Despite being a major cause of exacerbation, reports linking respiratory viruses to acute exacerbations only start to emerge in the late 1950s (Pattemore et al., 1992) ; with bacterial infections previously considered as the likely culprit for acute exacerbation 	episode_done:True
text: What did the advent of PCR technology lead to?	labels:  viruses were recovered during acute exacerbations events and reports implicating their role emerged in the late 1980s	episode_done:True
text: What are the predominant viruses linked to airway inflammatory diseases?	labels: Rhinovirus (RV) and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) 	episode_done:True
text: What other viruses are implicated in acute exacerbations but to a much lesser extent?	labels: parainfluenza virus (PIV), influenza virus (IFV) and adenovirus (AdV)	episode_done:True
text: What other viruses have been recently reported as contributing to acute exacerbations?	labels:  viruses including bocavirus (BoV), human metapneumovirus (HMPV), certain coronavirus (CoV) strains, a specific enterovirus (EV) strain EV-D68, human cytomegalovirus (hCMV) and herpes simplex virus (HSV)	episode_done:True
text: What are the common feature of these viruses share?	labels: they can infect both the upper and/or lower airway, further increasing the inflammatory conditions in the diseased airway	episode_done:True
text: Where do the respiratory viruses primarily infect and replicate?	labels: within airway epithelial cells 	episode_done:True
text: What happens  during the replication process?	labels: the cells release antiviral factors and cytokines that alter local airway inflammation and airway niche 	episode_done:True
text: What does the inflammation lead to in healthy airways?	labels: leads to type 1 inflammatory responses consisting of activation of an antiviral state and infiltration of antiviral effector cells. This eventually results in the resolution of the inflammatory response and clearance of the viral infection 	episode_done:True
text: How may the responses be different in a chronically inflamed airway?	labels:  the responses against the virus may be impaired or aberrant, causing sustained inflammation and erroneous infiltration, resulting in the exacerbation of their symptoms (Mallia and Johnston, 2006; Dougherty and Fahy, 2009; Busse et al., 2010; Britto et al., 2017; Linden et al., 2019) . This is usually further compounded by the increased susceptibility of chronic airway inflammatory disease patients toward viral respiratory infections, thereby increasing the frequency of exacerbation as a whole	episode_done:True
text: What will the review focus on?	labels: compiling and collating the current known mechanisms of viral-induced exacerbation of chronic airway inflammatory diseases; as well as linking the different viral infection pathogenesis to elucidate other potential ways the infection can exacerbate the disease	episode_done:True
text: How will this review serve?	labels: to provide further understanding of viral induced exacerbation to identify potential pathways and pathogenesis mechanisms that may be targeted as supplementary care for management and prevention of exacerbation.	episode_done:True
text: Why is this approach significant?	labels: due to the current scarcity of antiviral drugs for the management of viral-induced exacerbations.	episode_done:True
text: What happens upon infection?	labels: viruses evoke an inflammatory response as a means of counteracting the infection.	episode_done:True
text: How does the infected airway cell respond?	labels: Generally, infected airway epithelial cells release type I (IFNÎ±/Î²) and type III (IFNÎ») interferons, cytokines and chemokines such as IL-6, IL-8, IL-12, RANTES, macrophage inflammatory protein 1Î± (MIP-1Î±) and monocyte chemotactic protein 1 (MCP-1) (Wark and Gibson, 2006; Matsukura et al., 2013) .	episode_done:True
text: What  does the epithelial proteins cause?	labels: enable infiltration of innate immune cells and of professional antigen presenting cells (APCs) that will then in turn release specific mediators to facilitate viral targeting and clearance, including type II interferon (IFNÎ³), IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, IL-9, and IL-12 (Wark and Gibson, 2006; Singh et al., 2010; Braciale et al., 2012) .	episode_done:True
text: What is the effect of these factors?	labels: These factors heighten local inflammation and the infiltration of granulocytes, T-cells and B-cells (Wark and Gibson, 2006; Braciale et al., 2012) . The increased inflammation, in turn, worsens the symptoms of airway diseases.	episode_done:True
text: What additional effects are caused  in patients with asthma and patients with CRS with nasal polyp ?	labels: viral infections such as RV and RSV promote a Type 2-biased immune response (Becker, 2006; Jackson et al., 2014; Jurak et al., 2018) . This amplifies the basal type 2 inflammation resulting in a greater release of IL-4, IL-5, IL-13, RANTES and eotaxin and a further increase in eosinophilia, a key pathological driver of asthma and CRSwNP	episode_done:True
text: What is the result of increased eosinophilia?	labels: worsens the classical symptoms of disease and may further lead to life-threatening conditions due to breathing difficulties	episode_done:True
text: What are the effects for patients with COPD and patients with CRS without nasal polyp (CRSsNP) ?	labels: are more neutrophilic in nature due to the expression of neutrophil chemoattractants such as CXCL9, CXCL10, and CXCL11 (Cukic et al., 2012; Brightling and Greening, 2019) . The pathology of these airway diseases is characterized by airway remodeling due to the presence of remodeling factors such as matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) released from infiltrating neutrophils (Linden et al., 2019) . Viral infections in such conditions will then cause increase neutrophilic activation; worsening the symptoms and airway remodeling in the airway thereby exacerbating COPD, CRSsNP and even CRSwNP in certain cases 	episode_done:True
text:  Which are the type 2 inflammatory cytokines expressed by the epithelial cells upon injury to the epithelial barrier?	labels:  IL-25, IL-33 and TSLP 	episode_done:True
text: Which cells lacking both B and T cell receptors but play a crucial role in secreting type 2 cytokines to perpetuate type 2 inflammation when activated ?	labels:  ILC2s are a group of lymphoid cells	episode_done:True
text: What is the effect cell death and injury to the epithelial barrier due to infection?	labels: induce the expression of IL-25, IL-33 and TSLP, with heighten expression in an inflamed airway	episode_done:True
text: What happens when the 3 cytokines are expressed?	labels: These 3 cytokines then work in concert to activate ILC2s to further secrete type 2 cytokines IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 which further aggravate the type 2 inflammation in the airway causing acute exacerbation (	episode_done:True
text: What  happens in the case of COPD?	labels:  increased ILC2 activation, which retain the capability of differentiating to ILC1, may also further augment the neutrophilic response and further aggravate the exacerbation	episode_done:True
text: What happens during viral infection of healthy individuals?	labels:  these factors are not released to any great extent and do not activate an ILC2 response during viral infection in healthy individuals (Yan et al., 2016; Tan et al., 2018a) ; despite augmenting a type 2 exacerbation in chronically inflamed airways (Jurak et al., 2018) . These classical mechanisms of viral induced acute exacerbations are summarized in Figure 1 	episode_done:True
text: What happens upon viral infection in the airway?	labels: antiviral state will be activated to clear the invading pathogen from the airway. Immune response and injury factors released from the infected epithelium normally would induce a rapid type 1 immunity that facilitates viral clearance. 	episode_done:True
text: What is the effect of the inflammation of the airway?	labels:  However, in the inflamed airway, the cytokines and chemokines released instead augmented the inflammation present in the chronically inflamed airway, strengthening the neutrophilic infiltration in COPD airway, and eosinophilic infiltration in the asthmatic airway. The effect is also further compounded by the participation of Th1 and ILC1 cells in the COPD airway; and Th2 and ILC2 cells in the asthmatic airway.	episode_done:True
text: What increases the severity of exacerbations in the airway?	labels: the synergistic effect of viral infection with other sensitizing agents 	episode_done:True
text: Why viruses do not need to directly infect the lower airway to cause an acute exacerbation?	labels: he nasal epithelium remains the primary site of most infections.	episode_done:True
text: what is suggested by the fact that  not all viral infections of the airway lead to acute exacerbations?	labels: a more complex interplay between the virus and upper airway epithelium which synergize with the local airway environment in line with the "united airway" hypothesis 	episode_done:True
text: What is the effect of chronic airway inflammatory disease  in patients?	labels: viral infections or their components persist in patients	episode_done:True
text: What is the effect of chronic airway inflammatory disease?	labels: may further alter the local environment and contribute to current and future exacerbations	episode_done:True
text: Why should future studies  be performed using metagenomics in addition to PCR analysis ?	labels: to determine the contribution of the microbiome and mycobiome to viral infections.	episode_done:True
text: What is highlighted by the authors in this review?	labels:  recent data regarding viral interactions with the airway epithelium that could also contribute to, or further aggravate, acute exacerbations of chronic airway inflammatory diseases.	episode_done:True
text: Who has impaired or reduced ability of viral clearance ?	labels: Patients with chronic airway inflammatory diseases 	episode_done:True
text: What does their impairment stems from?	labels: a type 2-skewed inflammatory response which deprives the airway of important type 1 responsive CD8 cells that are responsible for the complete clearance of virusinfected cells 	episode_done:True
text: Where is this  especially evident?	labels: in weak type 1 inflammation-inducing viruses such as RV and RSV	episode_done:True
text: What are other  effects?	labels: there are also evidence of reduced type I (IFNÎ²) and III (IFNÎ») interferon production due to type 2-skewed inflammation, which contributes to imperfect clearance of the virus resulting in persistence of viral components, or the live virus in the airway epithelium 	episode_done:True
text: What is the  effect of viral components remaining in the airway?	labels: antiviral genes such as type I interferons, inflammasome activating factors and cytokines remained activated resulting in prolong airway inflammation	episode_done:True
text: What do these factors do?	labels: enhance granulocyte infiltration thus prolonging the exacerbation symptoms. Such persistent inflammation may also be found within DNA viruses such as AdV, hCMV and HSV, whose infections generally persist longer (Imperiale and Jiang, 2015) , further contributing to chronic activation of inflammation when they infect the airway	episode_done:True
text: What is also linked with the chronic inflammation that precedes the malignancies?	labels: human papilloma virus (HPV), a DNA virus highly associated with head and neck cancers and respiratory papillomatosis,	episode_done:True
text: What should be investigated in the future?	labels:  the role of HPV infection in causing chronic inflammation in the airway and their association to exacerbations of chronic airway inflammatory diseases, which is scarcely explored	episode_done:True
text: What further can viral persistence lead to?	labels: viral persistence which lead to continuous expression of antiviral genes may also lead to the development of steroid resistance, which is seen with RV, RSV, and PIV infection	episode_done:True
text: What  effect the use of steroids to  suppress inflammation can have?	labels: may also cause the virus to linger longer in the airway due to the lack of antiviral clearance	episode_done:True
text: What should be further focus of research?	labels: The concomitant development of steroid resistance together with recurring or prolong viral infection 	episode_done:True
text: Which viruses may not cause prolonged inflammation due to strong induction of antiviral clearance?	labels: viruses that induce strong type 1 inflammation and cell death such as IFV (Yan et al., 2016; Guibas et al., 2018) and certain CoV (including the recently emerged COVID-19 virus)	episode_done:True
text: What do these infections cause?	labels: massive damage and cell death to the epithelial barrier, so much so that areas of the epithelium may be completely absent post infection (Yan et al., 2016; Tan et al., 2019) . Factors such as RANTES and CXCL10, which recruit immune cells to induce apoptosis, are strongly induced from IFV infected epithelium 	episode_done:True
text: What do the necroptotic factors such as RIP3 do?	labels:  further compounds the cell deaths in IFV infected epithelium . The massive cell death induced may result in worsening of the acute exacerbation due to the release of their cellular content into the airway, further evoking an inflammatory response in the airway 	episode_done:True
text: What  may the destruction of the epithelial barrier  cause?	labels:  further contact with other pathogens and allergens in the airway which may then prolong exacerbations or results in new exacerbations.	episode_done:True
text: What may the epithelial destruction cause?	labels: may also promote further epithelial remodeling during its regeneration as viral infection induces the expression of remodeling genes such as MMPs and growth factors . Infections that cause massive destruction of the epithelium, such as IFV, usually result in severe acute exacerbations with non-classical symptoms of chronic airway inflammatory diseases.	episode_done:True
text: What is recommended that patients with chronic airway inflammatory disease?	labels:  receive their annual influenza vaccination as the best means to prevent severe IFV induced exacerbation.	episode_done:True
text: What is another mechanism that viral infections use to drive acute exacerbations?	labels: the induction of vasodilation or tight junction opening factors which may increase the rate of infiltration. 	episode_done:True
text: What does infection of respiratory viruses cause?	labels: disruption of tight junctions with the resulting increased rate of viral infiltration. This also increases the chances of allergens coming into contact with airway immune cells.	episode_done:True
text: What is an example of this?	labels:  IFV infection was found to induce oncostatin M (OSM) which causes tight junction opening (Pothoven et al., 2015; Tian et al., 2018) . Similarly, RV and RSV infections usually cause tight junction opening which may also increase the infiltration rate of eosinophils and thus worsening of the classical symptoms of chronic airway inflammatory diseases 	episode_done:True
text: What are also associated with viral infections and pneumonia development, which may worsen inflammation in the lower airway?	labels:  the expression of vasodilating factors and fluid homeostatic factors such as angiopoietin-like 4 (ANGPTL4) and bactericidal/permeabilityincreasing fold-containing family member A1 (BPIFA1)	episode_done:True
text: What is another area of interest?	labels: the relationship between asthma and COPD exacerbations and their association with the airway microbiome.	episode_done:True
text: What is usually linked with the development of chronic airway inflammatory diseases?	labels: specific bacterial species in the microbiome which may thrive in the inflamed airway environment 	episode_done:True
text: What follows  in the event of a viral infection such as RV infection?	labels:  the effect induced by the virus may destabilize the equilibrium of the microbiome present (Molyneaux et al., 2013; Kloepfer et al., 2014; Kloepfer et al., 2017; Jubinville et al., 2018; van Rijn et al., 2019) . In addition, viral infection may disrupt biofilm colonies in the upper airway (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae) microbiome to be release into the lower airway and worsening the inflammation	episode_done:True
text: What does the viral infection alter?	labels: the nutrient profile in the airway through release of previously inaccessible nutrients that will alter bacterial growth	episode_done:True
text: What is  the destabilization is further compounded by?	labels:  impaired bacterial immune response, either from direct viral influences, or use of corticosteroids to suppress the exacerbation symptoms	episode_done:True
text: What does all this gradually lead to?	labels: more far reaching effect when normal flora is replaced with opportunistic pathogens, altering the inflammatory profiles 	episode_done:True
text: Why do these changes may  result in more severe and frequent acute exacerbations ?	labels: due to the interplay between virus and pathogenic bacteria in exacerbating chronic airway inflammatory diseases 	episode_done:True
text: How effective are microbiome based  trial therapies?	labels:  have shown efficacy in the treatments of irritable bowel syndrome by restoring the intestinal microbiome (	episode_done:True
text: What can viral infections cause?	labels: the disruption of mucociliary function, an important component of the epithelial barrier. 	episode_done:True
text: Which is the primary contact/infection site of most respiratory viruses?	labels: The upper airway epithelium	episode_done:True
text: What does the destruction of epithelial barrier, mucociliary function and cell death of the epithelial cells do?	labels: serves to increase contact between environmental triggers with the lower airway and resident immune cells.	episode_done:True
text: What are viral infections are usually accompanied with?	labels: oxidative stress which will further increase the local inflammation in the airway. 	episode_done:True
text: What is the dysregulation of inflammation can be further compounded by?	labels: modulation of miRNAs and epigenetic modification such as DNA methylation and histone modifications that promote dysregulation in inflammation	episode_done:True

text: What does mucus overproduction do?	labels:  disrupt the equilibrium of the mucociliary function following viral infection, resulting in symptoms of acute exacerbation	episode_done:True
text: What does the disruption of the ciliary movement during viral infection may cause?	labels: MicroRNAs (miRNAs)	episode_done:True
text: What are MicroRNAs(miRNA)?	labels: short non-coding RNAs involved in post-transcriptional modulation of biological processes, and implicated in a number of diseases 	episode_done:True
text: What are  miRNAs found to be induced by?	labels:  viral infections and may play a role in the modulation of antiviral responses and inflammation 	episode_done:True
text: What  were linked to the exacerbation of the airway inflammation disease?	labels: circulating miRNA changes	episode_done:True
text: Where might such miRNA changes have originated from?	labels: from the infected epithelium and responding immune cells, which may serve to further dysregulate airway inflammation leading to exacerbations.	episode_done:True
text: What are both IFV and RSV infections shown to do?	labels:  to increase miR-21 and augmented inflammation in experimental murine asthma models, which is reversed with a combination treatment of anti-miR-21 and corticosteroids	episode_done:True
text: What are IFV infection shown to do?	labels:  increase miR-125a and b, and miR-132 in COPD epithelium which inhibits A20 and MAVS; and p300 and IRF3, respectively, resulting in increased susceptibility to viral infections 	episode_done:True
text: What happens in in asthmatic epithelium in IFV infection?	labels: miR-22 was shown to be suppressed in asthmatic epithelium in IFV infection which lead to aberrant epithelial response, contributing to exacerbations 	episode_done:True
text: What do non-coding RNAs present as?	labels: as targets to modulate viral induced airway changes as a means of managing exacerbation of chronic airway inflammatory diseases.	episode_done:True
text: What mechanisms, other than miRNA modulation play a role?	labels: epigenetic modification such as DNA methylation 	episode_done:True
text: What have  recent epigenetic studies indicated?	labels: the association of epigenetic modification and chronic airway inflammatory diseases, and that the nasal methylome was shown to be a sensitive marker for airway inflammatory changes (Cardenas et al., 2019; Gomez, 2019) .	episode_done:True
text:  What have these studies also shown?	labels:  viral infections such as RV and RSV alters DNA methylation and histone modifications in the airway epithelium which may alter inflammatory responses, driving chronic airway inflammatory diseases and exacerbations	episode_done:True
text: What has Spalluto et.al. have shown?	labels: that antiviral factors such as IFNÎ³ epigenetically modifies the viral resistance of epithelial cells.	episode_done:True
text:  What infections such as RV and RSV that weakly induce antiviral responses may result in?	labels:  an altered inflammatory state contributing to further viral persistence and exacerbation of chronic airway inflammatory diseases 	episode_done:True
text: What can viral infection result in?	labels:  enhanced production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction in the airway epithelium 	episode_done:True
text: What sustains the inflammation  in the airway?	labels: state of constant oxidative stress 	episode_done:True
text: What may viral infections of the respiratory epithelium by viruses such as IFV, RV, RSV and HSV do?	labels: may trigger the further production of ROS as an antiviral mechanism	episode_done:True
text: What can happen  in response to the infection such as neutrophils?	labels:  infiltrating cells in response to the infection such as neutrophils will also trigger respiratory burst as a means of increasing the ROS in the infected region. The increased ROS and oxidative stress in the local environment may serve as a trigger to promote inflammation thereby aggravating the inflammation in the airway 	episode_done:True
text: In addition to worsening disease symptoms, what do viral-induced exacerbations do?	labels:  also may alter the management of the disease or confer resistance toward treatments that worked before. 	episode_done:True

text: What can cause a slowing growth in daily reported deaths?	labels: significant impact of interventions implemented several weeks earlier.	episode_done:True
text: When did Italy go into Iockdown?	labels: 11th March	episode_done:True
text: Approximately how many deaths have been averted in Western Europe with current non-pharmaceutical interventions remaining in place until the end of March?	labels: 59,000 deaths	episode_done:True
text: What are some non-pharmaceutical interventions?	labels: case isolation, the closure of schools and universities, banning of mass gatherings and/or public events, and most recently, widescale social distancing including local and national Iockdowns	episode_done:True
text: Type of model used to infer the impact non-pharmaceutical interventions?	labels: semi-mechanistic Bayesian hierarchical model	episode_done:True
text: How can a semi-mechanistic Bayesian hierarchical model estimate changes to the reproductive number?	labels: calculating backwards from the deaths observed over time to estimate transmission that occurred several weeks prior, allowing for the time lag between infection and death.	episode_done:True
text: What is a key assumption of a semi-mechanistic Bayesian hierarchical model used for coronavirus?	labels: each intervention has the same effect on the reproduction number across countries and over time	episode_done:True
text: What is the time lag between when transmission changes occur and when their impact can be observed in trends in mortality?	labels: 2-3 weeks	episode_done:True
text: What is the key aim of non-pharmaceutical interventions?	labels: reduce the effective reproduction number	episode_done:True
text: What happens if the reproduction number is greater then 1?	labels: infections will increase (dependent on how much greater than 1 the reproduction number is)	episode_done:True
text: When did China introduce strict movement restrictions and other measures including case isolation and quarantine?	labels: 23rd January	episode_done:True
text: What was the result of China's interventions introduced in January?	labels: downward trend in the number of confirmed new cases during February	episode_done:True
text: What are examples of social distancing?	labels: banning large gatherings and advising individuals not to socialize outside their households	episode_done:True

text: What ways to  solve the issues are outlined?	labels: by creatively leveraging the so-called 'strengths' of viruses. Viral RNA polymerisation and reverse transcription enable resistance to treatment by conferring extraordinary genetic diversity. 	episode_done:True
text: How do these exact processes ultimately restrict viral infectivity?	labels:  by strongly limiting virus genome sizes and their incorporation of new information. 	episode_done:True
text: What does the author coin this evolutionary dilemma as?	labels: 'information economy paradox'.	episode_done:True
text: How do many viruses resolve this ?	labels: by manipulating multifunctional or multitasking host cell proteins (MMHPs), thereby maximising host subversion and viral infectivity at minimal informational cost.	episode_done:True
text: How may this "Achilles Heel" be safely targeted?	labels:  via host-oriented therapies to impose devastating informational and fitness barriers on escape mutant selection.	episode_done:True
text: Why  may MMHP-targeting therapies exhibit both robust and broadspectrum antiviral efficacy?	labels: since MMHPs are often conserved targets within and between virus families,	episode_done:True
text: What will  achieving this through drug repurposing do?	labels:  break the vicious cycle of escalating therapeutic development costs and trivial escape mutant selection, both quickly and in multiple places. 	episode_done:True

text: When was it  determined that the 1918  pandemic was caused by the H1N1 Influenza virus?	labels: That question did not begin to be resolved until the 1930s, when closely related inï¬uenza Viruses (now known to be H1N1 Viruses) were isolated, ï¬rst from pigs and shortly thereafter from humans. text: Did the Spanish Influenza or Swine flu or the H1N1 virus disappear in humans for some time?	labels:  descendants of the 1918 Virus still persists enzootically in pigs. They probably also circulated continuously in humans, undergoing gradual antigenic drift and causing annual epidemics, until the 1950s. With the appearance of a new H2N2 pandemic strain in 1957 (âAsian ï¬uâ), the direct H1N1 Viral descen- dants 0f the 1918 pandemic strain disappeared from human circulation entirely, although the related lineage persisted enzootically in pigs.	episode_done:True

text: What descendant  lineages of the swine flu (Spanish Influenza) virus were identified in 2006?	labels:  2 major descendant lineages of the 1918 H1N1 Virus, as well as 2 additional reassortant lineages, persist naturally: a human epidemic/endemic H1N1 line- age, a porcine enzootic H1N1 lineage (so-called classic swine ï¬u), and the reassorted human H3N2 Virus lineage, which like the human H1N1 Virus, has led to a porcine H3N2 lineage.	episode_done:True

text: Should I practice social distancing?	labels: Together, we can slow the spread of COVID-19 by making a conscious effort to keep a physical distance between each other. Physical (social) distancing is proven to be one of the most effective ways to reduce the spread of illness during an outbreak. This means making changes in your everyday routines to minimize close contact with others, including:avoiding crowded places and non-essential gatherings avoiding common greetings, such as handshakes limiting contact with people at higher risk like older adults and those in poor health keeping a distance of at least 2 arms-length (approximately 2 metres) from others	episode_done:True

text: Should I practice social distancing?	labels: If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to be tested. text: Should I practice social distancing?	labels: Face masks, including fabric ones, are likely only helpful in preventing people who have COVID-19 from spreading it to others. If you wear a cloth mask, you should still use the same social distancing measures as you would if you were not wearing a mask. This means you should stay at least 6 feet (2 meters) away from other people, wash your hands frequently, and avoid touching your face or eyes.When wearing a mask, make sure it covers your nose and mouth. Wash the mask after you use it every time. When handling the mask, act as though the front of the mask is contaminated. Don't touch the front of the mask when you take it off or put it on.It is not recommended that the general public wear surgical or N95 masks at this time. That is because there are not enough of these masks for health care workers. Health care workers need these masks to stay safe and to take care of sick patients. If you have extra surgical or N95 masks, please donate them to your local healthcare facility.	episode_done:True
text: Should I practice social distancing?	labels: Social distancing means maintaining a physical distance (approximately 6 feet or 2 meters) from others you do not live with. This includes when you're inside a store or outside for exercise. The COVID-19 virus spreads easily from person-to-person. It travels through the air when a sick person coughs, sneezes or talks. One way to contain the spread of COVID-19 is to stop people from sharing it. Without a vaccine or treatment, we can help contain the virus by: Staying at home to protect others if you are sick. Staying home is still the best way to lower our risk of COVID-19, but small groups of 10 or fewer people are now allowed if health and safety precautions are followed. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family. Continuing to go outside, take walks, do essential errands while maintaining a physical distance from others and practicing proper hygiene. Remember that ticks are active this time of year. Find out how to Be Tick Smart and prevent tick bites. Wearing a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain, especially at the grocery store, pharmacy, doctorÃ¢ÂÂs office, hospital or other essential business or office, and on a crowded sidewalk or bike path. Washing your hands (adults and children) any time you go inside, before you eat, and before you spend time with people who are more vulnerable to the effects of COVID-19.	episode_done:True

Only go out when you really need to (for groceries, for example) 2. If you do go out, keep at least 6 foot (2 meter) distance between you and other people. 3. Wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, using the restroom, coming home and before eating or makng food. ALWAYS wash your hands with soap and water if your hands are visibly dirty.4. If you don't have soap and water, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol. 5. Clean and disinfect surfaces that people touch a lot (e.g. tables, countertops, light switches, door knobs, cabinet handles). If you or someone in your family gets sick, stay at home, except when getting medical care, until your doctor says you no longer have to stay home. Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissues, and throw the tissue away.	episode_done:True
text: Someone from quarantaine came to my office and stayed 20min Is it a risk?	labels: Generally, do not touch the body of someone who has died of COVID-19. We are still learning how COVID-19 spreads and if a deceased body can transmit the virus. One could get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it, and then touching their face (like their mouth, nose, or eyes). Try to avoid kissing washing, and shrouding the body. If washing and shrouding the body are important in your culture or religion, work with your community cultural and religious leaders as well as funeral home staff to try to reduce exposure as much as possible. People who conduct these activities should wear disposable gloves. If fluid splashing is expected, more personal protective equipment may be needed, such as disposable gowns, goggles, and face masks.	episode_done:True
